Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to introduce a fully integrated current sensor with an order of magnitude performance improvement over the state-of-art technologies. The developed technology will enable more reliable, efficient and compact power electronics systems. Power electronics is an integral part of today's power delivery systems such as renewable energy systems, electric vehicles, data centers and most consumer electronics. In these applications, electric current information is often an essential parameter that needs to be known and measured for control, diagnostic and prognostic purposes. With advances in power electronic circuits with specific attention to high frequency power converters, there is a need to investigate alternative approaches and techniques to measure the current. These approaches should result in availability of current sensors that have fast-response, are accurate, loss-less, and preferably non-intrusive. The impact of such a sensor is to enable systems and circuits that will be miniaturized and more efficient through the use of wide band-gap semiconductors and high switching frequencies. Additionally, the availability of current measurement information will lead to greater reliability and prognostic capability. Applications include power converters in electric vehicles and data centers.

This I-Corps project will explore the commercial potential of the current sensor technology in different industry sectors such as automotive, telecommunications, and data centers. Today, there is no current sensor that can be used in many power electronics systems or integrated into semiconductor modules optimized to operate with switching frequencies beyond 1MHz. This project will address the need and requirements for such sensors by moving away from commonly-used Hall-Effect sensors and utilizing magneto-resistors. With proprietary IC circuitry and packaging, the project team is developing contactless, lossless sensors with bandwidths up to 10 MHz, while overcoming the measurement challenges due to EMI, asymmetrical current distributions and non-uniform magnetic field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the summer of 2017, our team participated in the NSF Icorps program to find specific customer segments and value propositions enabled by our sensing technology through traveling and speaking with potential customers directly. We interviewed 115 potential customers as well as partners, suppliers, distributers, and influencers. A highlight of the customer interviews by segment is the attached figure.

Our search resulted in identifying two prominent product-market fits. Circuit designers utilizing GaN semiconductors identified miniaturization enabled by high switching speed and reduced magnetics. Engineers with products utilizing SiC identified device failure from shoot through current due to higher susceptibility to inadvertent turn-on as a pain point which can be mitigated by protection enabled by ultrafast current sensing.

Of the two, the most immediate need is protection for SiC devices as these products have begun entering the industrial, renewable, automotive, and datacenter industries. Mitigation mechanisms exist, such as oversizing the semiconductor, but such methods are not as cost effective as our proposed sensor. Currently there is no commercially available isolated sensor that is fast enough to detect current transients in the 100's of nanoseconds range necessary for device protection.

Companies researching GaN enabled converters in the automotive and aerospace industries expressed the most interest in the value of increased power density. We learned that the automotive industry in particular is investing heavily in electric vehicles as Volkswagen announced in September 2017 an $84 billion investment in electric vehicles and batteries. Through our interviews, we learned that increased power density enables electric vehicles to reach more commercial and industrial applications, achieve better performance including fuel efficiency and cooling requirements, and even increase safety due to packaging improvements.

In addition to a better understanding of the overall market, we learned specific details customers require in terms of the current sensor product, including the desired current range, package form factor, required speed (not only bandwidth but response time), necessary sensitivity and accuracy, and competitive price point.
